translated: and after saying â€œof infinite knowledgeâ€ he says â€œof infinite splendourâ€ and so on. Herein, of infinite knowledge : his knowledge is without limit either in the sense of number or in the sense of excellence. Of infinite splendour : his knowledge is of infinite splendour in the sense of the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in the mental continuities of those who are teachable. Of infinite fame : his fame is spread out in the three worlds without limit by means of the excellence of his knowledge. Rich : he is rich in the abundance of the wealth of knowledge. Greatly wealthy : his wealth of knowledge is great because of the greatness of his excellence, in other words, he is greatly wealthy. Or alternatively, the reading is â€œmahÄdhanaâ€ , and the meaning is that he is greatly wealthy because of the greatness of his wealth of knowledge. Possessed of wealth : he is possessed of the wealth of knowledge that is praiseworthy.

translated: and after showing his knowledge as infinite, he shows his glory as infinite, etc., in the next line. translated: He shows this in the stanza beginning, â€œThe Leader, the Controller, the Guide, the One who shows the way.â€ Herein, the Leader is he who leads beings from the place of fear called the round of rebirths to the place of security called NibbÄna. The Guide is he who guides beings by the way of the eightfold path at the time of teaching the Dhamma. The One who shows the way is he who shows the way to the city of NibbÄna. The One who knows the way is he who knows the way to the city of NibbÄna. The One who goes the way is he who goes the way to the city of NibbÄna. The One who has crossed over and gone beyond is he who has crossed over and gone beyond the ocean of the round of rebirths. The One who has reached the goal is he who has reached the goal of the welfare of himself and others. The One who has passed beyond the pathways is he who has passed beyond the four pathways.

translated: He has him whipped: he has him beaten with canes. He has him flogged with the leather strap: he has him beaten with a whip. He has him fettered in wooden fetters: he has him fettered with wooden fetters. He has him fettered in iron fetters: he has him fettered with iron fetters. He has him confined in stocks: he has him confined in a cage. He has him confined in prison: he has him confined in a prison. He has him banished: he has him expelled from the country. He has him deprived of his property: he has his property confiscated. He has him mutilated: he has a hand or a foot or a nose cut off. He has him sewn up in a sack: he has him sewn up in a sack and thrown into the water. He has him devoured by dogs: he has him thrown to dogs to eat. He has him impaled alive on a stake: he has him impaled alive on a stake. He has him beheaded: he has his head cut off with a sword.ğŸ”½He has him devoured by vultures: he has him thrown to vultures to eat. He has him devoured by hawks: he has him thrown to hawks to eat. He has him devoured by herons: he has him thrown to herons to eat. He has him devoured by tigers: he has him thrown to tigers to eat. He has him devoured by hyenas: he has him thrown to hyenas to eat. He has him devoured by wolves: he has him thrown to wolves to eat. He has him devoured by dogs: he has him thrown to dogs to eat. He has him devoured by various creatures: he has him thrown to various creatures to eat. He has him burned on a pyre: he has him thrown on a pyre and burned. He has him drowned: he has him thrown into the water and drowned.
